fields.Notes:
From Levi Posak, Amara volunteer who produced current captions: "There was a video by Suri, a Yiddish speaker on wikitongues. I transliterated the video, and then also translated the video to English. There was a slight problem though: I didn't understand two words she said in the video. The speaker mentioned "Maysns" Yiddish, or something like that, and I'm not familiar with that word. She also said "Gemain", which I'm also not familiar with. The rest of the video I understood clearly, and translated it. One last "issue" (more like information that may be wondered) is that in the video I translated questions with "He said "...?"". Even though it's a question being asked, tbe speaker said "he/she said" instead of "he/she asked". The reason why I didn't write "asked" even though the person asked the speaker a question is because I wanted to stay true to what the speaker is actually saying. I hope that makes sense? 
For example: 
Speaker Suri: He (a stranger) said "where are you from?". 
Even though the stranger is asking a question, Suri doesn't say "he asked me..." She stated "he said..." Even though that's quite wrong for English as well as Yiddish, I still translated it to how she said it in Yiddish, with the mistake and all. I hope that makes more sense. Thank you "
Demographics: 215,000 in Israel (1986). Population total all countries: 1,505,030.
YouTube License Statement: This video is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International license. To download a copy, please contact hello@wikitongues.org.
fields.Geneaology: "[ Indo-European, Germanic, West, High German, Yiddish ]"
